address.verbatim-address: Secretariat: Accra, Ghana

org-entry.found-date: 2017, with a focus on 3 pillars: information and intelligence sharing; training security and intelligence personnel; and conducting jt cross-border military security operations
org-entry.content-note: implemented, in 3 phases, border security Operation Koudanlgou during 2018-19
an MOU aimed at enhancing security and intelligence co-operation among the mem. states was concluded in 2020
an international conf. convened in Nov. 2022, in Accra, called for the operationalization of a Multinational Joint Task Force of the Accra Initiative
in May 2023 the Secretariat of the Accra Initiative and the ECOWAS Commission agreed to co-ordinate their respective strategies focused on combating terrorism and transnational crime
org-entry.stats: mems: Benin, Burkina Faso, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Togo; observers: Mali, Niger

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: African Association for Public Administration and Manage­ment (AAPAM)

address.verbatim-address: 132 Fuchsia Close, POB 48677, 00100 GPO, Nairobi, Kenya

org-entry.found-date: 1971 to promote good practices, excellence and professionalism in public administration through training, seminars, research
org-entry.content-note: convenes regular confs to share learning experiences among mems, and an annual Roundtable Conference (2023: July, in Livingstone, Zambia)
funded by membership contributions, govt and donor grants
org-entry.stats: mems: 500 individual, 50 corp., 15 nat. chapters
org-entry.content-note: publs Newsletter (quarterly), Annual Seminar Report , African Journal of Public Ad­min­istration and Management (2 a year)

address.verbatim-address: BP V314, Abidjan, Côte d'Ivoire

org-entry.found-date: 1976 (as Union of African Parliaments)
org-entry.content-note: aims to promote democracy and to facilitate interaction between African legislators and parliamentary institutions
org-entry.stats: mems: 41 parliaments

address.verbatim-address: 89 Abdel Aziz Al-Saoud St, POB 11559-61 Manial El-Roda, Cairo, Egypt

org-entry.content-note: acts among and for the peoples of Africa and Asia in support of genuine independence, sovereignty, socioeconomic devt, peace and disarmament
holds General Congress normally every 2 years
holds observer status of the Non-Aligned Movement
org-entry.stats: mems: nat. cttees and affiliated orgs in 90 countries and territories, assoc. mems in Europe and Latin America

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Agency for the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons in Latin America and the Caribbean
org-entry-head.alt-name: Organismo para la Proscripción de las Armas Nucleares en la América Latina y el Caribe—OPANAL

address.verbatim-address: Milton 61, Col Anzures, Delegación Miguel Hidalgo, 11590 Ciudad de México, Mexico

org-entry.found-date: 1969 to ensure compliance with the Treaty for the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons in Latin America (Treaty of Tlatelolco), 1967
org-entry.content-note: to ensure the absence of all nuclear weapons in the application zone of the Treaty
to contribute to the movement against the proliferation of nuclear weapons
to promote general and complete disarmament

to prohibit all testing, use, manufacture, acquisition, storage, installation and any form of possession, by any means, of nuclear weapons; the organs of the Agency comprise the General Conference, meeting every 2 years, the Council, meeting every 2 months, and the secretariat
org-entry.stats: mems: 33 states that have fully ratified the Treaty
org-entry.content-note: the Treaty has 2 additional Protocols: the first signed and ratified by France, the Netherlands, the UK and the USA, the second signed and ratified by the People’s Rep. of China, France, the Russian Fed., the UK and the USA

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Alianza Bolivariana para los Pueblos de Nuestra América-Tratado de Comercio de los Pueblos—ALBA-TCP
org-entry-head.alt-name: Bolivarian Alliance for the Peoples of our America-People’s Trade Treaty

address.verbatim-address: Avda Francisco Solano, Esq. Calle San Gerónimo, Edif. Los Llanos, 8° Sabana Grande, Parroquia El Recreo, Caracas, Venezuela

org-entry.found-date: 2002 (as the Bolivarian Alternative for the Americas) by the then Pres. of Venezuela, Hugo Chávez, to promote an alternative model of political, economic and social co-operation and integration between Caribbean and Latin American countries sharing geographic, historical and cultural bonds
org-entry.content-note: aims to reduce disparities in devt between countries in the region and to combat poverty and social exclusion
the so-called People’s Trade Treaty (Tratado de Comercio de los Pueblos) was signed in April 2006 to formalize a process of complementarity
in June 2007 the inaugural meeting of ALBA's Council of Ministers agreed to the establishment of jt enterprises, as an alternative to transnational corpns
the establishment of the Caracas-based Banco del ALBA (BANALBA), to finance devt projects, was endorsed at the 6th summit meeting of heads of state, convened in Jan. 2008

the use of a Unified System of Regional Compensation (Sistema Único de Compensación Regional—SUCRE) as a means of currency exchange for commercial transactions between mems was agreed in 2009 and first used in 2010
the agreement establishing SUCRE, signed in Oct. 2009, also envisaged the establishment of a Regional Monetary Council, a Central Clearing House, a regional reserve and emergency fund
in Feb. 2012 the Ecconomic Complementation Council agreed to establish an ALBA-TCP economic space (ECOALBA)
in May 2013 mems agreed to strengthen co-operation with Petrocaribe through the establishment of a new economic zone to promote regional investment, trade, food security, tourism and devt projects
a summit meeting between the 2 orgs, convened in Dec., agreed to develop mechanisms to support the economic zone initiative

in March 2015 ALBA condemned an Executive Order of the USA which had imposed sanctions against 7 Venezuelan officials and had described that country as posing `an extraordinary and unusual threat’ to US national security

the 14th summit, convened in Caracas, Venezuela, in March 2017, pledged solidarity with Venezuela and called for Latin American unity and solidarity, while reiterating condemnation of the continuing US sanctions regime against that country; the summit also pledged solidarity with Mexico, with regard to the US-Mexico border wall and anti-immigration policies planned by the US Administration of Donald Trump
the 15th summit meeting, held in March 2018, condemned Peru’s decision not to invite Venezuela to the 8th Summit of the Americas (convened in April)
Ecuador announced its withdrawal from ALBA in Aug., further to a deterioration in bilateral relations with Venezuela

in Nov. 2019 Bolivia’s interim govt, established following the resignation of Pres. Evo Morales, announced that country’s withdrawal from ALBA (the decision was reversed, however, by newly-elected Pres. Luis Arce in Nov. 2020)
in June 2020 the ALBA leaders determined to establish an ALBA Humanitarian Fund, under the auspices of the BANALBA
Cuba hosted the 20th, 21st and 22nd summit meetings, held in Dec. 2021, May 2022 and Dec. 2022, respectively
in Jan. 2023 the grouping condemned extremist violence at govt buildings in Brazil and attempts to undermine the authority of that country’s newly elected Pres. Lula da Silva

ALBA-TCP participated in July in the 4th Inter-Secretariat Meeting of subregional integration mechanisms, convened at the hq of the Latin American Integration Association , in Montevideo, Uruguay, with a focus on productive chains

in Jan. 2024 the grouping issued a statement that condemned a recent Argentine judicial order that had supported a request from the USA to confiscate a Boeing 747 cargo aircraft registered to a Venezuelan co., Emtrasur (a subsidiary of Venezuela’s state-owned airline Conviasa); the aircraft had been detained at Ezeiza International Airport (Buenos Aires, Argentina) in June 2022, in view of `administrative irregularities’: the USA asserted that it had been transferred to Emtrasur from the Iranian airline Mahan Air, in violation of US counter-terrorism legislation relating to transactions involving merchandise originally exported from the USA
org-entry.stats: mems: Antigua and Barbuda, Bolivia, Cuba, Dominica, Grenada, Nicaragua, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Venezuela

org-entry.content-note: aims to promote co-operation and trade promotion for sustainable development, based on the commitment to democratic institutions, respect for human rights and the rule of law

working to achieve concrete actions within the framework of five axes: regional leadership, migration and refuge; environmental sustainability and climate change; security, justice and fight against corruption; and economic growth and sociolabour opportunities
org-entry.stats: mems: Costa Rica, Dominican Rep., Ecuador, Panama

org-entry.content-note: envisaged as a mutual defence pact to counter any military intervention by the Economic Community of West African States by signatories of the Liptako-Gourma Charter, concluded in Sept. 2023 by the military regimes of Burkina Faso (which had taken power in Sept. 2022, following a first coup in Jan. of that year), Mali (May 2021, following on from an initial military takeover in Aug. 2020), and Niger (July 2023)

address.verbatim-address: c/o 685 Third Ave, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10017, USA

org-entry.content-note: serves to focus attention on the specific problems of small islands and low-lying coastal developing states (SIDS)
activities cover the Caribbean; Africa, the Indian Ocean, the Mediterranean and the South China Sea—`AIMS’; and the Pacific

in 2014, reps of the 3 SIDS regions led a strategy governing the UN-designated International Year of Small Island Developing States, culminating in the Third International Conference on SIDS, convened, in Sept., in Apia, Samoa
supports immediate and effective implementation of the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change

convened the (virtual) Placencia Ambition Forum 2020 in April of that year, with a focus on safeguarding the Paris Agreement and highlighting the global climate change priorities of small islands, and—given the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 crisis—contributing towards sustaining the momentum of the climate agenda

convened a Wadadli Action Platform in Antigua, in Aug. 2022, which again highlighted the challenges facing SIDS and formulated priorities for consideration by the 4th International Conference on SIDS (SIDS4)
participated, in Jan. 2024, in the Preparatory Cttee for SIDS4, scheduled to be held in Antigua and Barbuda, in May
chairmanship rotates (2024: Samoa)
org-entry.stats: mems: 39 island nations and observers

address.verbatim-address: c/o Dept of Foreign Affairs and Trade, R. G. Casey Bldg, John McEwen Crescent, Barton, ACT 0221, Australia

org-entry.content-note: the ANZUS Security Treaty, signed in 1951 by Australia, New Zealand and the USA, aimed to co-ordinate partners' efforts for collective defence for the preservation of peace and security in the Pacific area, through the exchange of technical information and strategic intelligence, and a programme of exercises, exchanges and visits

in 1984 New Zealand refused to allow visits by US naval vessels that were either nuclear-propelled or potentially nuclear-armed, which led to the cancel­lation of jt ANZUS military exercises: in 1986 the USA formally announced the suspension of its security commitment to New Zealand under ANZUS; instead of the annual ANZUS Council meetings, ministerial consultations (AUSMIN) were subsequently held every year between Australia and the USA on policy and political-military issues; ANZUS continued to govern security relations between Australia and the USA, and between Australia and New Zealand
the Australian Govt invoked the ANZUS Security Treaty for the first (and by 2024 only) time following the international terrorist attacks perpetrated in Sept. 2001 against targets in the USA
strategic co-operation between the USA and New Zealand resumed after 2010, and in Sept. 2012 the USA removed a ban on New Zealand naval vessels using its ports

address.verbatim-address: Unit 1 b , Bldg 201, Maarad St, Marfaa Area, Beirut, Lebanon

org-entry.content-note: aims to strengthen contacts and promote dialogue between Arab parliamentarians, to co-ordinate activities at international forums, to enhance democratic concepts and values in the Arab countries, to co-ordinate and unify Arab legislation, and to strengthen Arab solidarity
org-entry.stats: mems from 22 countries

address.verbatim-address: Al Salam, Block 7, St 27, House 14, Kuwait City, Kuwait

org-entry.content-note: aims—without duplicating the work of other orgs—to build an Asian Community, and to strengthen Asia's competitiveness by maximizing the diversity and rich resources in the continent
promotes interdependence among Asian countries in all areas of co-operation; aims to expand trade and financial markets within Asia
mems: 35 countries

address.verbatim-address: 3 f Pohang Techno Park, No. 601 Gigok-dong, Nam-gu, Pohang, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Republic of Korea

org-entry.stats: mems: 79 local govts in 6 countries (People’s Rep. of China, Japan, Mongolia, Democratic People’s Rep. of Korea, Rep. of Korea, Russian Fed.)

org-entry.found-date: 1981 to provide a permanent structure of mutual assistance for representatives of the people of the Pacific Islands
org-entry.content-note: comprises legislative reps from 12 Pacific Island Govts

org-entry.content-note: studies the law, practice and working methods of different parliaments
proposes measures for improving those methods and for securing co-operation between the services of different parliaments
operates as a consultative body to the Inter-Parliamentary Union, and assists it on subjects within the scope of the Asscn
publ. Constitutional and Parliamentary Information (2 a year)

address.verbatim-address: 20 rue des Petits Carmes, 1000 Brussels, Belgium

org-entry.content-note: aims to promote the goals of the North Atlantic Treaty Org. (NATO), and to enhance the solidarity of the peoples of the North Atlantic
holds annual assemblies, seminars, study confs for teachers and young politicians
incorporates a youth wing (YATA)
org-entry.stats: mems: nat. asscns in NATO mem. states

org-entry.found-date: Sept. 2021
org-entry.content-note: a trilateral security agreement, under the terms of which the USA and the UK were to assist Australia with the acquisition of nuclear-powered submarines and collaboration was to be enhanced with respect to advanced defence technologies

in March 2023 the parties to the agreement announced that they had agreed on 3 stages for the implementation of the initiative, to be undertaken over the next 3 decades: training and capacity building; the acquisition of complete, conventionally armed, nuclear-powered submarines; and the acquisition of complete, welded power units for submarines to be built in Australia
org-entry.stats: mems: Australia, UK, USA

address.verbatim-address: Citadeles St 2-616, Rīga 1010, Latvia

org-entry.content-note: aims to promote co-operation among the parliaments of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania

comprises 12 parliamentarians from each country, who participate in 6 working cttees: Budget and Audit; Security and Defence; Natural Resources and Environment; Health, Welfare and Family; Education, Science and Culture; and Economics, Energy and Innovation
holds annual sessions
in 1994 the Assembly and the Baltic Council of Ministers formed the Baltic Council, as an institution of co-operation
since 1996 has also held jt sessions with the Nordic Council to promote co-operation in Northern Europe
the presidency rotates between the participating states (2024: Lithuania)

org-entry.found-date: 1993 by the Baltic Assembly
org-entry.content-note: comprises 60 parliamentarians from Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania
co-ordinates policy in the areas of foreign policy, justice, the environment, education and science
holds an annual meeting

since 2003 the country holding the rotating presidency of the Baltic Assembly also presides over the Council, ensuring common priorities and organizational efficiency between both bodies (2024: Lithuania)

address.verbatim-address: POB, 9900, Wiulls Gate 3, Kirkenes, Norway

org-entry.found-date: 1993 as a forum for Barents intergovernmental co-operation
org-entry.content-note: permanent secretariat established in 2007
a Barents Financial Mechanism was established in 2022 to help fund projects supporting co-operation and sustainable devt in the region
from March 2022 suspended all state-level co-operation with Russia, following that country’s invasion of Ukraine, and closed local offices in Russia
chairmanship of the Council rotates on a 2-yearly basis between the mem. states
org-entry.stats: mems: Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Russian Fed., Sweden, European Commission

org-entry.content-note: inaugural meeting of heads of state of the 5 littoral Caspian Sea states was held in Aşgabat, Turkmenistan, in April 2002, in order to further discussions on the status and demarcation of the sea
a special working group, at the level of deputy mins responsible for foreign affairs, had been established in 1996 to negotiate a legal framework on the shared use of the Caspian Sea
subsequent summits were convened in Tehran, Iran, in Oct. 2007, Baku, Azerbaijan, in Nov. 2010, and Astrakhan, Russian Fed., in Sept. 2014

in Aug. 2018, at the 5th summit meeting, convened in Aktau, Kazakhstan, heads of state signed the Convention on the Legal Status of the Caspian Sea, as well as protocols to previous intergovernmental agreements

the accords were to govern the shared resources and security of the sea, inter alia, through the delineation of territorial and exclusive fishing rights, the prohibition of any foreign military presence, and strengthened co-operation in maritime shipping, transport interconnection and the prevention of incidents
a business forum and a Caspian Youth Summit took place at the sidelines of the summit for the first time in 2010
the First Caspian Economic Forum was convened in Aug. 2019, in Awaza, Turkmenistan
org-entry.stats: mems: Azerbaijan, Iran, Kazakhstan, Russian Fed., Turkmenistan

org-entry.found-date: 1961 to foster co-operation between the 6 Celtic nations—Ireland (Éire), Scotland (Alba), Isle of Man (Mannin), Wales (Cymru), Cornwall (Kernow) and Brittany (Breizh), especially those actively working for political autonomy by non-violent means
org-entry.content-note: campaigns politically on issues affecting the Celtic countries
monitors military activity in the Celtic countries
co-operates with national cultural orgs to promote the languages and culture of the Celts
org-entry.stats: mems: approx. 1,400 individuals in the European traditionally Celtic communities, as well as a general international branch, and local branches based in England, USA, Nova Scotia (Canada) and Patagonia (Argentina)
org-entry.content-note: publ. Carn (quarterly)

address.verbatim-address: CEI Executive Secretariat, Via Genova 9, 34121 Trieste, Italy

org-entry.found-date: 1989 as `Quadragonal’ co-operation between Austria, Italy, Hungary and Yugoslavia, became `Pentagonal' in 1990 with the admission of Czechoslovakia, and `Hexagonal’ with the admission of Poland in 1991, present name adopted in 1992, when Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia and Slovenia were admitted
org-entry.content-note: the Czech Rep. and Slovakia became separate mems in Jan. 1993, and the former Yugoslav rep. of Macedonia (now North Macedonia) also joined in that year
Albania, Belarus, Bulgaria, Romania and Ukraine joined in 1995 and Moldova in 1996
the Federal Rep. of Yugoslavia (now the separate sovereign states of Montenegro and Serbia) was admitted in 2000

encourages regional political and economic co-operation with a focus on: climate, environment and sustainable energy; enterprise devt (incl. tourism); human resource devt; information society and media; intercultural co-operation (incl. minorities); multimodal transport; science and technology; sustainable agriculture; interregional and cross-border co-operation

in May 2020 the CEI and WHO Regional Office for Europe established a jt task force, comprising senior health officials from CEI mem. states, to co-ordinate the regional response to the COVID-19 pandemic
a CEI Cooperation Fund, financed by the Italian Govt and managed by the EBRD, was est. in 1992
economic forum held annually since 1998
rotating presidency (2024: Albania); maintains a troika mechanism, comprising the current, most recent and next presidencies
org-entry.stats: mems: 17 states (Belarus suspended in March 2022)
org-entry.content-note: publ. Newsletter (monthly)

address.verbatim-address: 10 rue du Commerce, 1000 Brussels, Belgium

org-entry.found-date: 1961 as Christian Democrat and Peoples' Parties International, present name adopted in 1999
org-entry.content-note: serves as an asscn of political groups adhering to Christian humanist and democratic theology
org-entry.stats: mems: 109 political parties in 83 countries

address.verbatim-address: Palacio del Marqués de Cañete, Calle Mayor 69, Planta 1, 28013 Madrid, Spain

org-entry.found-date: 2001, following Conference on Democratic Transition and Consolidation
org-entry.content-note: forum of democratically elected former Presidents and Prime Ministers
aims to strengthen democratic values and leadership
org-entry.stats: mems: 124 from 73 countries

org-entry.found-date: Jan. 2020, in Pau, France, by the heads of state of the G5 Sahel countries and of France
org-entry.content-note: aims to provide a framework for co-operation with a wider grouping of international partners to counter terrorism in the sub-region, to strengthen the capacities of G5 states to impose order within all their territories, and to harness humanitarian and devt assistance

address.verbatim-address: 101100 Moscow, per. Sverchkov 3/2, Russian Federation

org-entry.found-date: 2003 by signatories to the Treaty on Collective Security (signed in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, May 1992)
org-entry.content-note: aims to co-ordinate and strengthen military and political co-operation and to promote regional and national security
became an observer at the UN General Assembly in 2004
in April 2006 signed a protocol with UNODC to develop jt projects to combat drug trafficking, terrorism and transborder crime

the Oct. 2007 leaders' summit endorsed documents enabling the establishment of CSTO jt peacekeeping forces and the creation of a co-ordination council for the heads of mem. states' emergency response agencies
in Feb. 2009 agreed to establish a rapid reaction force and conducted a jt military exercise in Aug.-Oct. (without the participation of Uzbekistan, which formally withdrew from the org. in 2012)
in March 2010 the CSTO and UN Secretaries-General signed a declaration on co-operation, giving the CSTO full recognition as a regional security body
in Sept. 2012 the CSTO and the UN Department of Peacekeeping Operations signed a Memorandum of Co-operation providing for the future expansion of collaboration on peacekeeping activities
the devt of a CSTO peacekeeping contingent, comprising experts, operational personnel and special units, was initiated in 2017
in Jan. 2022 authorized the dispatch of a collective peacekeeping mission to Kazakhstan, of some 2,030 troops, to counter civil unrest, secure key infrastructure facilities and restore order
in April a draft action plan on enhancing the CSTO’s crisis response capabilities was finalized
CSTO jt military exercises are regularly organized
org-entry.stats: mems: Armenia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Russian Fed., Tajikistan

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Community of Latin American and Caribbean States
org-entry-head.alt-name: Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños—CELAC

org-entry.content-note: heads of state of the fmr Rio Group (f. 1987) and Latin American and Caribbean Summit on Integration and Development agreed to merge to establish CELAC as a pan-regional body to strengthen co-operation on political, cultural, social and economic issues
inaugural summit held in Dec. 2011
the 2nd summit, held in Jan. 2013, in Santiago, Chile, was preceded by an inaugural CELAC-EU summit, at which a revised Action Plan for bilateral relations was adopted
the 3rd CELAC summit, convened in Jan. 2014, in Havana, Cuba, issued the Proclamation of Latin America and the Caribbean as a Zone of Peace
a 2nd CELAC-EU summit was held in June 2015

the inaugural CELAC-EU inter-summit meeting was convened in Oct. 2016, at which CELAC and EU mins responsible for foreign affairs determined to transform the Hamburg, Germany-based EU-Latin America and Caribbean Foundation (EU-LAC Foundation—est. in 2010)—into an int. org.; the EU-LAC Foundation Constitutive Agreement entered into force in May 2019
a China-CELAC Forum was convened in Jan. 2018
the creation of a wider Latin American and Caribbean sustainable economic devt zone has been addressed by CELAC and other regional orgs
in July 2021 CELAC condemned the assassination of Haitian President Jovenel Moïse, and emphasized support for a return in that country to constitutional order and the rule of law
the 6th summit meeting, held in mid-Sept. 2021, in Mexico City, Mexico, initiated a new CELAC fund for natural disaster response
in early Jan. 2023 the new Brazilian govt of Pres. Lula da Silva announced its return to full membership of CELAC (this having been suspended in Jan. 2020)

later in that month the 7th summit meeting was convened in Buenos Aires, Argentina, at which heads of state and govt expressed their commitment to regional integration and upholding democracy and the rule of law; they also called for an end to the US sanctions against Cuba, support for Venezuelan political dialogue and greater provision of credit by multilateral financial institutions to assist mem. states to counter the economic impact of COVID-19, climate change and the ongoing war in Ukraine; the meeting was addressed by Pres. Xi of China, who confirmed his country’s recognition of CELAC as a key partner in furthering greater Chinese co-operation with the region

the 3rd CELAC-EU summit of heads of state or of govt, organized in July 2023, in Brussels, Belgium, adopted an EU-CELAC Roadmap for the period 2023-25, providing for bi-regional ministerial and other high-level meetings, other gatherings, fora and events, and the First Bi-regional Connectivity Policy Dialogue
the 8th summit meeting was held at the beginning of March 2024, in Kingstown, St Vincent and the Grenadines

an emergency summit was to be convened on 12 April, to address a diplomatic crisis that had arisen between Ecuador and Mexico (following an Ecuadorian raid against the Mexican Embassy in Quito, Ecuador, to arrest former Ecuadorisn Vice-Pres. Jorge Glas)
rotating presidency (2024: Honduras)
org-entry.stats: mems: 31 Latin American and Caribbean states

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty Organization (CTBTO), Preparatory Commission

address.verbatim-address: Vienna International Centre, POB 1200, 1040 Vienna, Austria

org-entry.found-date: 1996 upon the adoption by the UN General Assembly of the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT)
org-entry.content-note: promotes the global norm of a moratorium on nuclear testing, supports verification of the Treaty and prepares for its entry into force, including the establishment of verification structures to ensure compliance with its provisions

the org. operates some 133 International Monitoring System (IMS) facilities which relay information to an International Data Centre, based at the Vienna headquarters; IMS data also supports climate-related activities including tsunami warnings

at April the CTBT had 178 states parties; to enter into force it required universal ratification by the 44 `Annex II’ states with known nuclear capacities—those remaining at that time were the People’s Rep. of China, the Democratic People’s Rep. of Korea, Egypt, India, Iran, Israel, Pakistan, the Russian Fed. and the USA
in Oct. 2023 Russia had revoked a previous ratification—to ensure parity with the USA, which had signed but not as yet ratified the treaty

role-group.role: Exec. Sec. of the Provisional Technical Secretariat

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Comunidade dos Países de Língua Portuguesa

address.verbatim-address: rua de S. Mamede (ao Caldas) 21, 1100-533 Lisbon, Portugal

org-entry.content-note: aims to produce close political, economic, diplomatic and cultural links between Portu­guese-speaking countries and to strengthen the influence of the Lusophone Commonwealth within the international community
Lisbon-based CPLP Parliamentary Assembly inaugurated in Nov. 2007
in Nov. 2010 adopted, jtly with ECOWAS, the CPLP-ECOWAS roadmap on reform of the defence and security sector in Guinea-Bissau
in April 2017 the CPLP Exec. Sec. held consultations with national and international stakeholders in Guinea-Bissau to address an ongoing paralysis of the political process in that country
a jt military exercise, Exercício FELINO, is conducted periodically by mem. states

summit meeting normally held every 2 years (14th was convened in São Tomé and Príncipe, in Aug. 2023, on the theme `Youth and Sustainability’); a CPLP strategic plan was being implemented during 2016-26
in July 2019, with the Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN, opened a new Training Centre for Sustainable Family Farming, based in São Tomé and Príncipe
org-entry.stats: mems: Angola, Brazil, Cabo Verde, Equatorial Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Portugal, São Tomé and Príncipe (holding the rotating presidency during 2023-25), Timor-Leste; 19 assoc. observers

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Conference on Interaction and Confidence Building Measures in Asia

address.verbatim-address: 010000 Astana, 55/20 Mangilik Yel. Ave, Kazakhstan

org-entry.content-note: aims to provide a structure to enhance co-operation, and to promote peace, security and stability throughout the region
inaugural meeting of heads of state held in June 2002, adopted the AlmatI Act
a secretariat was established in June 2006

activities focused on a catalogue of confidence-building measures grouped as: economic dimension; environmental dimension; human dimension; fight against new challenges and threats (such as drug trafficking, terrorism, transborder crime, human trafficking, money laundering, illicit trade in small arms and light weapons); and military-political dimension
has supported the Heart of Asia-Istanbul Process

at the 6th summit meeting, held in Oct. 2022, in Astana, mems resolved to transform the legal status of the grouping into an international org.; the role of Exec. Dir was renamed Sec.-Gen. and a Deputy Sec.-Gen. was to be appointed
org-entry.stats: mems: 28 states; 10 observer states; 5 observer orgs (UN, OSCE, League of Arab States, IOM, and Parliamentary Assembly of Turkic States)

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Council for Security Co-operation in the Asia-Pacific

address.verbatim-address: Institute of Strategic and International Studies (ISIS Malaysia), 1 Persiaran Sultan Salahuddin, POB 12424, 50778 Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

org-entry.content-note: aims to contribute to regional confidence-building efforts and to enhance regional security through dialogue, consultation and co-operation between academics, officials and other stakeholders
org-entry.stats: mems: 21 full and 1 assoc.
org-entry.content-note: publs CSCAP Regional Security Outlook (CRSO) (annually), CSCAP General Conference Reports (2 a year)

address.verbatim-address: Afrika Mashariki Rd/EAC Close, Arusha, Tanzania

org-entry.content-note: established under the East African Community’s founding Treaty as the legislative organ of the Community
the first sitting of the 5th tenure (2022-27) of the Assembly was held in Jan. 2023
72 mems (63 elected and 9 ex officio)

org-entry.found-date: 2005 as a regional forum for strategic dialogue and co-operation
org-entry.content-note: covers the following areas of co-operation: economy and trade; education; environment and energy; finance; food security; global health issues and pandemic diseases; natural disaster management; and ASEAN connectivity
annual meetings of heads of state and of govt are held, usually after the ASEAN summit meeting; other ministerial or senior officials’ meetings are convened during the year
an EAS Declaration on the Principles for Mutually Beneficial Relations was issued in Nov. 2011 (when the Russian Fed. and USA participated fully for the first time)
in 2015 the 10th EAS, held in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, in Nov., resolved to strengthen the grouping as an institution and to enhance co-operation

an EAS Plan of Action to cover the period 2024-28 was adopted in July 2023 by EAS ministers responsible for foreign affairs; the 18th Summit was organized by Indonesia in Sept. 2023, in Jakarta, with guest representation from the Pacific Islands Forum and Indian Ocean Rim Association
org-entry.stats: mems: ASEAN states, Australia, People’s Rep. of China, India, Japan, New Zealand, Rep. of Korea, Russian Fed., USA

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Eastern Regional Organization for Public Administration (EROPA)

address.verbatim-address: National College of Public Administration, University of the Philippines, Diliman, Quezon City 1101, Philippines

org-entry.content-note: promotes regional co-operation in improving knowledge, systems and practices of governmental ad­min­istration, to help to accelerate economic and social devt
organizes confs, seminars, special studies, surveys and training programmes

there are 5 regional centres: Training Centre (New Delhi, India), Local Government Centre (Tokyo, Japan), Development Man­age­ment Centre (Seoul, Rep. of Korea), Human Resources Research Center (Beijing, People’s Rep. of China), Policy Studies Center (Jakarta, Indonesia)
holds annual conf. (2023: Ha Noi, Viet Nam, in Oct., on the theme `The Role of Public Governance in Socio-Economic Recovery and Development Towards the SDGs’)
org-entry.stats: mems: People’s Rep. of China, India, Indonesia, Iran, Japan, Malaysia, Rep. of Korea, Nepal, Philippines, Thailand, Viet Nam
org-entry.content-note: publs EROPA Bulletin (quarterly), Asian Review of Public Administration (2 a year)

address.verbatim-address: 3 Tilney St, London, W1K 1BJ, United Kingdom

org-entry.found-date: July 2007, by former Pres. of South Africa, Nelson Mandela
org-entry.content-note: a group of independent world leaders offering collective influence and experience

aims to support the peaceful resolution of conflict, to seek new approaches to unresolved global issues and to share wisdom in all efforts to uphold human rights, to counter climate change and to alleviate human suffering

an Elders' Strategy being implemented during 2023-27 focused on resolving conflicts, and on addressing 3 existential threats to humanity that require a collective response: the climate crisis, nuclear weapons, and pandemics

comprises: Mary Robinson (Ireland) (Chair.), Ban Ki-Moon (Rep. of Korea), Graça Machel (Mozambique), Gro Harlem Brundtland (Norway), Helen Clark (New Zealand), Elbegdorj Tsakhia (Mongolia), Zeid Raad al-Hussein (Jordan), Hina Jilani (Pakistan), Ellen Johnson Sirleaf (Liberia), Ricardo Lagos (Chile), Juan Manuel Santos (Colombia), Ernesto Zedillo (Mexico)
the following maintain the positions of Elder Emeritus: Lakhdar Brahimi (Algeria), Fernando H. Cardoso (Brazil), Jimmy Carter (USA)

address.verbatim-address: 2 pl. du Luxembourg, 1050 Brussels, Belgium

org-entry.found-date: 1947 to promote the concepts of European unity
org-entry.content-note: brings together reps of civil society, political parties, trade unions, local govt and academia to consider issues relating to the European Union
advocates for policies to support European integration
promotes an annual Women of Europe Awards
org-entry.stats: mems: nat. councils and cttees in 34 European countries, and 38 int. social and economic orgs, 3 supporting mems

org-entry.found-date: 2022 (the format having first been proposed in May by Pres. Emmanuel Macron of France)
org-entry.content-note: conceived of as a broad platform to promote inter-European exchange of views, political dialogue and co-operation with respect to Europe-wide strategic challenges, with a view to strengthening continental stability, security, peace and prosperity
the format is informal,:as such the participants do not issue collective formal declarations
meetings between European leaders may take place in smaller (e.g. bilateral, trilateral) groupings on the sidelines of the EPC’s summits

inaugural summit held in Oct. 2022, in Prague, Czech Rep., with participation by the heads of state or govt of the 27 EU mem. states (the European Council of the EU agreed in June 2022 to support the EPC format), the 4 European Free Trade Association countries (i.e. Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland), the UK, 6 non-EU Western Balkans countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Serbia), 5 Eastern European countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine), and Türkiye
subsequent summits were to be convened biannually, hosted alternately by EU and non-EU mems; the 2nd summit was held in June 2023, in Bulboaca, Moldova; 3rd: in Oct., in Granada, Spain
intelligence alliance developed from the UK-US Communication Agreement that was signed in 1946 by the UK and USA and subsequently joined by Australia, Canada and New Zealand

in 2020 the grouping considered whether to broaden its scope into an economic partnership for pooling strategic reserves such as medical supplies and critical minerals (i.e. rare earth elements that are used as components in consumer and defence products)—with a view to countering strategic dependencies on the People’s Republic of China
participation by Japan is under consideration

2023 Five Country Ministerial (FCM) meeting: Wellington, New Zealand, in June, focused on the following themes: countering foreign interference; cybersecurity; engagement with tech industry; countering violent extremism and terrorism; tackling child exploitation and abuse online; migration; national resilience; and fentanyl and the opioid crisis

address.verbatim-address: ILOT ZRA 742 BIS, rue Monotel, Tevragh Zeina, Nouakchott, Mauritania

org-entry.content-note: aims to promote security, devt, good governance and resilience in the Sahel region
a UN-supported G5 unit is tasked with preventing extremist radicalization

determined in Feb. 2017 to establish a counter-terrorism force—Force conjointe du G5 Sahel (FC-G5S)—tasked with combating violent extremist groups operating in the G5 common space; the FC-G5S was to comprise up to 5,000 military and police personnel
in April the AU Peace and Security Council endorsed the strategic concept of operations of the FC-G5S and authorized its deployment, which was then endorsed by the UN Security Council in June

it was announced in Aug. that the FC-G5S had become operational; a co-ordinated operation along Mali's borders with Burkina Faso and Niger was undertaken in early Nov.; in Dec. the UN Security Council determined to extend further technical support to the force
a FC-G5S Trust Fund has been established

in Jan. 2020, at a summit attended in Pau, France, by the G5 Sahel heads of state, Pres. Emmanuel Macron of France and the UN Sec.-Gen., a Niamey, Niger-based jt command mechanism was established between the FC-G5S and French Opération Barkhane (then deployed in the region to support action against terrorist insurgencies); the strategic concept of operations of the FC-G5S was revised at that time; the meeting endorsed the establishment of a new Coalition for the Sahel, as a collaborative framework between the G5 Sahel and international partners to promote peace, stability and devt assistance throughout the sub-region; in March the Force initiated Operation Sama in the Sahel region
the 6th ordinary G5 Sahel summit, held in Feb., in Nouakchott, agreed to create a G5 Sahel Exec. Secretariat
the 7th summit was hosted by Chad, in N'Djamena, in Feb. 2021

in Feb. 2022 Pres. Macron announced that Opération Barkhane was to be withdrawn from Mali (this was undertaken by Aug.); meanwhile, mercenaries of the Wagner Group, a Russian private paramilitary and security contractor, were reported to be increasingly active in Mali
Mali withdrew from the G5 Sahel in June, reportedly after the grouping denied its transitional authorities from assuming its forthcoming presidency
in Jan. 2023 Burkina Faso’s military junta demanded that France withdraw its forces from Burkinabè territory
a 6th extraordinary G5 Sahel summit meeting was convened in N’Djamena in Feb. 2023 at a time of escalating violent extremism
following the overthrow of the elected Nigerien Government in July France announced that it would withdraw its forces from Niger by the end of the year
in Sept. the military regimes of Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso signed a new security pact, the Alliance of Sahel States
in early Dec. Burkina Faso and Niger announced they were to withdraw from the org.; Chad and Mauritania reportedly were considering its dissolution
org-entry.stats: mems: Chad, Mauritania

address.verbatim-address: c/o Ministry of Finance, Dili, Timor-Leste

org-entry.content-note: asscn of countries either presently affected by conflict or in a post-conflict stage of devt, promotes co-operation between mems and highlights the specific needs of those countries
granted observer status at the UN General Assembly in Dec. 2019, and associated observer at the CPLP in Aug. 2021
org-entry.stats: mems: 20 countries

org-entry.content-note: operates as a multilateral platform with a focus on strengthening the international architecture for addressing terrorism
promotes a strategic, long-term approach to countering terrorism and related violent extremist ideologies

develops good practices and tools for policymakers on challenges such as returning foreign terrorist fighters, the role of families in preventing violent extremism, and preventing kidnapping for ransom by terrorists, and maintains the GCTF Foreign Terrorist Fighters Knowledge Hub
a GCTF Lifecycle Initiative Toolkit has been developed to enable policymakers to address the pathways from radicalization and violence
issued the Hague-Marrakech Memorandum on Good Practices for a More Effective Response to the Foreign Terrorist Fighters (FTF) Phenomenon in 2016
supports the implementation of the UN’s Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy, as well as the UN Sec.-Gen.’s Plan of Action to Prevent Violent Extremism (publ. in 2016)
org-entry.stats: mems: 29 states and the European Union

org-entry.usage: ewyb edio casee mena fea eerca
org-entry.content-note: an informal meeting of major advanced economies, originally comprising France, Germany, Italy, Japan, UK and the USA, first convened in Nov. 1975, at Rambouillet, France, at the level of heads of state and of govt; Canada became a permanent participant in 1976

from 1991 the Russian Fed. was invited to participate in summit meetings outside the formal framework of co-operation and in 1997 Russia became a participant in nearly all meetings, excepting those related to finance and the global economy; from 1998 the name of the co-operation framework was changed to Group of Eight—G8, and during 2003-13 Russia participated fully in the grouping; from March 2014, however, owing to Russia’s interference in Ukraine’s domestic affairs and its recognition of Crimea (hitherto a Ukrainian autonomous territory) as a sovereign state, and subsequent annexation of Crimea, Russia’s participation was suspended, and the group reverted to its former membership and name

an annual meeting is convened, with the Presidents of the European Commission and the European Council, the chairmanship and venue of which are rotated; summit meetings address and seek consensus on social and economic issues confronting the international community

regular discussions at the level of ministers of finance and central bank governors take place to consider devts in the global economy and economic policy; sectoral ministerial meetings are also convened to address areas such as energy, the environment and foreign affairs

an emergency teleconference of G7 finance ministers and central bank governors was held in early March 2020 to discuss policy tools that might protect the global economy from the impacts of the COVID-19 global public health emergency

at a virtual summit meeting held in mid-April support was expressed by all leaders other than Pres. Trump for the ongoing efforts of the World Health Organization (WHO) and partner agencies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic (Trump, meanwhile, had recently suspended US funding to WHO)
at the end of May the USA, scheduled to be hosting the 46th summit meeting in the following month, postponed the gathering until later in the year; in the event, no summit was convened

at a virtual mini-summit gathering hosted by the UK in Feb. 2021 mem. states pledged US $7,500m. in additional funding to redress `vaccine inequality’ (the theme of the meeting) by accelerating the distribution of surplus COVID-19 vaccines to developing countries
in early June, meeting in London, UK, G7 finance ministers jtly agreed support for a global minimum corporate tax rate of 15%

the 2021 summit meeting—hosted by the UK, in Carbis Bay, Cornwall, in mid-June—pledged to secure a further 1,000m. COVID-19 vaccine doses over the next year for low- and middle-income countries; the so-called Carbis Bay Declaration also incl. commitments to continue to invest in research and innovation, with a view to ensuring the efficacy of vaccines against emerging variants of COVID-19; to engage constructively at the WTO on the issue of introducing temporary intellectual property waivers for COVID-19 vaccine patents; to support the strengthening of the global health system, incl. global surveillance for potentially dangerous diseases; to continue to support economies and protect employment, while investing in training, skills, innovation, and the creation of decent jobs and quality infrastructure; to support a new $650,000m. general allocation of IMF special drawing rights; to continue to pursue the goal of phasing out inefficient fossil fuel subsidies by 2025; to ensure that by 2026 40m. more girls are receiving education; and to co-operate with China, in particular on addressing climate change; the communiqué also called on China to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms, especially in relation to Xinjiang and Hong Kong

a virtual meeting of the G7 leaders, with participation by the Secs-Gen. of the UN and of NATO, was held in late Aug. to address the recent takeover of Afghanistan by the militant Taliban org.; at the end of Aug. a virtual meeting on Afghanistan was convened by the ministers responsible for foreign affairs of the G7 states, EU, Turkey (now known as Türkiye) and Qatar (which had assisted with the civilian evacuation process), again with participation by the NATO Sec.-Gen.; in Dec. G7 foreign ministers, convened in Liverpool, UK, condemned the Russian military build-up on its border with Ukraine and urged a de-escalation of tensions; the G7 strongly reaffirmed its commitment to Ukraine’s territorial integrity
org-entry.stats: in mid-Feb. 2022 the G7 stated its continuing grave concern over the `threatening military build-up’ of Russian forces around Ukraine, and called on Russia to resolve tensions through diplomatic channels and substantively to withdraw its military presence
org-entry.content-note: on 24 Feb., in response to Russia’s initiation on that day of a full-scale military invasion of Ukraine, the G7 leaders issued a statement that condemned the assault on Ukraine, terming it a serious threat to the UN Charter and rules-based international order
meeting in Brussels, in March, the G7 leaders determined to increase collective contributions to the World Food Programme and to other int. agencies concerned with alleviating food insecurity

a virtual meeting of G7 leaders held in early May, with participation by Pres. Zelensky of Ukraine, pledged to continue to provide Ukraine with military and defence support, to help strengthen the country’s energy and economic security, and to expand co-operation, including on information security; firm commitments were made at that time to (i) phase out dependency on Russian energy, including by phasing out or banning imports of Russian oil, through finding alternative suppliers and expediting the transition to clean energy sources; (ii) prohibit or prevent the provision of key services on which Russia depends; and (iii) continue to take action against Russian banks connected to the global economy and of systemically critical importance to the Russian financial system

at the annual summit, convened in late June, in Schloss Elmau, Germany, the leaders issued a communiqué in which they pledged to stand firmly by Ukraine, incl. through the provision of budgetary and humanitarian assistance, military aid, and support for Ukraine’s long-term reconstruction; the leaders also agreed to establish a Partnership for Global Infrastructure and Investment (PGII), which aimed to mobilize (by 2027) $600,000m. for projects in developing economies, and a G7 Climate Club, to promote climate actions aligned with the goals of the 2015 Paris Agreement, and committed to achieving a fully decarbonized electricity supply by 2035; some $4,500m. in additional funding was committed to a new G7 Global Alliance for Food Security that had been launched in May by a meeting of G7 ministers responsible for devt; the leaders determined generally to cease direct international public financing of fossil fuels by the end of 2022
in Aug. G7 foreign ministers and the High Representative of the EU called upon Russian forces immediately to give back to Ukraine full control of all of its nuclear facilities, to ensure their safety
meeting in Sept. the G7 finance ministers stated their collective political intention to impose a price cap on Russia’s oil exports, with a view to reducing that country’s revenues

the 49th G7 leaders’ summit was hosted by Japan in Hiroshima, in mid-May 2023, with additional invited participation by the leaders of Australia, Brazil, Comoros, Cook Islands, India, Indonesia, Republic of Korea, Viet Nam, and Ukraine; the ensuing Hiroshima Leaders’ Communiqué, emphasizing respect for the UN Charter and international partnership, reaffirmed unwavering support to Ukraine `for as long as it takes’ to counter Russia’s war of aggression, and committed (as detailed in a G7 Leaders’ Statement on Ukraine) to intensifying diplomatic, financial, humanitarian and military support for Ukraine, to increasing costs for Russia and supporters of its war, and to continuing to work towards mitigating the negative global impacts of the conflict (particularly for the most vulnerable people worldwide); the leaders issued a G7 Clean Energy Economy Action Plan, endorsed a series of Circular Economy and Resource Efficiency Principles, and—in a G7 Leaders’ Statement on Economic Resilience and Economic Security—determined to focus on diversifying and deepening partnerships, and on `de-risking’ economic activities (while stressing that sustainable economic relations with China, rather than a `decoupling’, were envisaged); the leaders issued a Hiroshima Action Statement for Resilient Global Food Security, and endorsed a G7 Global Plan for Universal Health Care Action Agenda, as well as an annex on a G7 Vision for Operationalising Data Free Flow with Trust (DEFT—aimed at combining enhanced cross-border data flows with strengthened data privacy and security; a G7 Action Plan for Promoting DEFT had been launched in May 2022); a G7 Leaders’ Hiroshima Vision on Nuclear Disarmament was issued by the May 2023 summit, which also emphasized the importance of ensuring a free and open, inclusive, prosperous, secure, rules-based Indo-Pacific
org-entry.stats: mems: Canada, France, Germany, Italy (holding the presidency in 2024), Japan, UK, USA; European Commission representation

address.verbatim-address: 01001 Kyiv, vul. Sofievska 2A, Ukraine

org-entry.content-note: Uzbekistan joined the grouping in April 1999, when it became temporarily known as GUUAM, but withdrew in May 2005
formally inaugurated as a full international org. and present name adopted by heads of state in May 2006
objectives incl. promoting a regional space of democracy, security, and stable economic and social devt
strengthening relations with the European Union and NATO
combating terrorism, organized crime, drug trafficking and related activities, incl. through the GUAM Virtual Law Enforcement Center
establishing a GUAM energy security council
creating the GUAM Free Trade Zone, in accordance with an agreement signed by heads of state meeting in Yalta, Ukraine, in July 2002
further economic devt, incl. the creation of an East-West trade corridor and transportation routes for petroleum
and participation in conflict resolution and peacekeeping activities

in June 2013 the CGG participated, with ECOWAS and CEEAC, in a regional summit on maritime safety and security, convened in Yaoundé, Cameroon, which adopted a Code of Conduct concerning the Prevention and Repression of Piracy, Armed Robbery against Ships, and Illegal Maritime Activities in West and Central Africa
in Sept. 2014, under the auspices of the 3 orgs, an Inter-regional Coordination Centre for Maritime Safety and Security in Central and West Africa was inaugurated, in Yaoundé
3rd extraordinary summit of heads of states or govt was convened in April 2023, in Accra, Ghana

presidency is held jtly by the incumbent Speakers of the UK House of Commons and House of Lords
publ. Parliamentary Affairs (quarterly)

Afghanistan’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs acts as the de facto Secretariat of the HOA-IP
9th HOA-IP ministerial conf.: March 2021, in Dushanbe, Tajikistan
subsequently inactive
org-entry.stats: it had been supported by 16 countries, and by orgs incl. the Asian Development Bank, Conference on Interaction and Confidence Building Measures in Asia, Economic Cooperation Organization, European Union, North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Organization of Islamic Cooperation, Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, Shanghai Cooperation Organization, and the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation

org-entry.content-note: provides institutional and technical support to the Ibero-American summit meetings, monitors programmes agreed at the meetings and strengthens the Ibero-American community

meetings of Ibero-American heads of state and of govt are held every 2 years (annually until 2014, the first of which was convened in Guadalajara, Mexico, in 1991) to promote political, economic and cultural co-operation

the 28th summit meeting, hosted by the Dominican Rep. in March 2023, focused on digital rights, food security, international financing, and environment and climate change; mems approved a third Quadrennial Action Plan for Ibero-American Cooperation (PACCI), covering the period 2023-26

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR)
org-entry-head.alt-name: Conference internationale sur la region des grands lacs

address.verbatim-address: POB 7076, 38 blvd du Japon, Bujumbura, Burundi

org-entry.found-date: 2006 following the signing of the Security, Stability and Development Pact for the Great Lakes Region at the 2nd summit meeting of the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, held in Dec., in Nairobi, Kenya
org-entry.content-note: the UN Security Council proposed in 2000 a Great Lakes Conference to initiate a process that would bring together regional leaders to pursue agreement on a set of principles and to articulate programmes of action to help to end the cycle of regional conflict and establish durable peace, stability, security, democracy and devt in the whole region
the inaugural summit meeting was convened in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, in Nov. 2004

the Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region (adopted by ICGLR heads of state and govt in Dec. 2006, entered into force in June 2008) provides a legal framework for the org.’s activities; 10 protocols that were also adopted in 2006 address: democracy and good governance; judicial co-operation; non-aggression and mutual defence in the Great Lakes Region; the illegal exploitation of natural resources; the prevention of the crime of genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity and all forms of discrimination; prevention and suppression of sexual violence against women and children; protection and assistance to IDPs; property rights of returning persons; and management of communication and information

the Executive Secretariat of the org. was inaugurated in May 2007 (main divisions and assoc. programmes of action: Peace and Security, Democracy and Good Governance, Economic Development and Regional Integration, Humanitarian and Social Issues, and Gender, Women and Children)

subsidiary institutions incl. the Lusaka, Zambia-based ICGLR Levy Mwanawasa Regional Centre for Democracy and Good Governance; ICGLR Regional Training Facility (based in Kampala, Uganda, and focused on sensitizing police units, and judicial and other officials to addressing cases of sexual violence); Joint Intelligence Fusion Centre; Expanded Joint Verification Mechanism (Goma, Democratic Rep. of the Congo—DRC); monitors and investigates security incidents); and the Joint Follow-up Mechanism (Kasese, Uganda; comprises counter-terrorism experts)
a Special Fund of Reconstruction and Development, hosted by the AfDB, was established in 2008

launched in 2009 the ICGLR Regional Initiative against the Illegal Exploitation of Natural Resources (known as the ICGLR RINR, and governed by a Regional Steering Cttee), which aims to break the link between revenues from illegal mining and the financing of rebel groups

in Dec. 2010 ICGLR heads of state and govt signed the Lusaka Declaration, identifying specific tools for the formation of an ICGLR RINR-related regional control mechanism, which incl. the establishment of an ICGLR Regional Certification Mechanism (ICGLR RCM) for natural resource supply chains (the RCM provides assurances to purchasers that gold, tantalum, tin and tungsten extracted in ICGLR mem. states have been sourced, transported, and exported legally); harmonization of national legislation; creation of a regional database on mineral flows; formalization of the artisanal mining sector; and establishment of a whistle-blowing mechanism

from 2012 the Conference worked to mediate between govt and rebel forces fighting in eastern DRC; agreement was reached in early Nov. to establish an Expanded Joint Verification Mechanism, to counter rebel groups fighting in that region; an emergency summit meeting was convened in Nov., in Kampala, Uganda, following the advance by the 23 March Movement (`M23’) grouping to take control of Goma (DRC)

in Feb. 2013 the leaders of 11 African countries signed the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework (PSCF) for the DRC and the Region, which aimed to stabilize the Great Lakes region; with the UN, the African Union and SADC , the ICGLR was tasked with guaranteeing the Framework; the signatories to the Framework committed to protect the future territorial sovereignty and the peace and stability of the DRC
an intervention brigade was mandated by the UN Security Council in the following month to target militias in eastern DRC

following the declaration by the M23, in early Nov., of the end of its rebellion in eastern DRC, a so-called Kampala dialogue was convened between the DRC Govt and the M23 leadership in Nov.-early Dec., culminating in the signing, under the auspices of the ICGLR and SADC, of final declarations by the parties, providing for, inter alia, an envisaged process of disarmament of former M23 combatants

in Jan. 2019 the ICGLR expressed concern at the outcome of the presidential part of a general election held on 30 Dec. 2018 in the DRC, and recommended a recount of votes cast; in mid-Jan. 2019, stating serious concern over the conformity of the official provisional result, the ICGLR, SADC and AU determined to dispatch a jt high-level delegation to the DRC to liaise with national stakeholders on means of resolving the post-electoral crisis; soon afterwards, however, despite continuing evidence of irregularities in the electoral process, Félix Tshisekedi was declared the victor in the presidential poll and promptly inaugurated
a mini summit of heads of state held in April 2021 initiated a working group to draft recommendations to guide consultations with armed groups in the CAR

an ICGLR workshop organized in late Aug.-early Sept. prepared a series of recommendations on strengthening the implementation of the ICGLR RINR, incl. an emphasis on combating impunity for those engaged in natural resources-related crimes
adopted in mid-Sept. a roadmap towards achieving peace in the CAR, focused on revitalizing the implementation of the (2019) Political Agreement on Peace and Reconciliation in the CAR

a mini summit on peace and security in the DRC, organized by the ICGLR in Nov. 2022, urged full compliance with regional peace initiatives focused on the DRC, and the cessation of all polito-military support to the M23 and other armed groupings active there
in Dec. the ICGLR stated grave concern at reports of massacres allegedly committed by M23 against civilians at the end of Nov. in Kishishe, North Kivu (DRC)
the 10th extraordinary ICGLR summit, held in June 2023, urged M23 and other domestic and foreign armed militants in the DRC to lay down arms and withdraw unconditionally

also in that month, a 1st quadripartite summit was convened under AU auspices, in Luanda (Angola), to address the harmonization of ongoing interventions in the DRC, with participation by the ICGLR, EAC , SADC , and Communauté Economique des Etats de l'Afrique Centrale (the `Quadripartite Platform’)
a Meeting of Chiefs of Defence of the Quadripartite was convened in Oct., in Addis Ababa

COVID-19, HIV/AIDS, refugees, preventing sexual and gender-based violence, and promoting the disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration of former militants were cross-cutting themes of the ICGLR’s activities in 2024
maintains centres in Goma, DRC, and Lusaka, Zambia
org-entry.stats: mems: Angola, Burundi, Central African Rep., Democratic Rep. of Congo, Rep. of the Congo, Kenya, Rwanda, South Sudan, Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia

in Aug. 2017 the ministers responsible for foreign affairs of 12 states, meeting in Lima, Peru, adopted the Lima Declaration, in which they resolved collectively to facilitate a peaceful resolution to the ongoing political crisis in Venezuela
membership was subsequently expanded

the Lima Group condemned as illegitimate the presidential election staged in Venezuela in May 2018, won by incumbent Pres. Nicolás Maduro Moros, and determined to reduce the level of diplomatic relations with Venezuela and to lobby international lenders to desist from offering loans to that country without prior approval from the Venezuelan National Assembly

in Jan. 2019, following the commencement of Maduro’s second term of office, the Lima Group supported a declaration by Juan Guaidó Márquez, Pres. of the Venezuelan National Assembly, that he had assumed the role of interim Pres. of Venezuela

in early Feb. 11 mem. states (excluding Guyana, Mexico and Saint Lucia) issued a jt statement calling for a peaceful change of power in Venezuela, for that country’s military to support Guaidó, and for international co-operation in taking measures to prevent the Maduro regime from conducting financial and trading transactions
in that month the Guaidó-led Venezuelan regime was admitted to the Lima Group
in Aug. 2020 the Group rejected plans by Maduro to stage legislative elections in Venezuela in Dec., deeming these to lack sufficient guarantees or breadth of participation
the elections went ahead, albeit boycotted by many opposition politicians, and in Jan. 2021 the Lima Group declared it would not recognize the legitimacy of the newly-installed National Assembly
in March Argentina announced its departure from the Group; Mexico left in May, and in Aug. Peru and Saint Lucia followed suit
in late Dec. 2022 the Venezuelan National Assembly voted to dissolve the position of interim Pres., with effect from 5 Jan. 2023

org-entry.content-note: NATO implements the objectives of the Atlantic Alliance, which was established on the basis of the 1949 North Atlantic Treaty and aims to provide common security for its mems through co-operation and consultation in political, military and economic fields, as well as scientific, environmental, and other non-military aspects

the highest authority of the Alliance is the North Atlantic Council (NAC), which meets at the level of permanent representatives of mem. countries, ministers of foreign affairs, defence ministers, or heads of state or govt (2023: Vilnius, Lithuania, in July)

in March 2011 NATO initiated Operation Unified Protector in order to monitor and enforce a UN-imposed arms embargo against the Libyan authorities; later in that month NATO mems determined to enforce the UN sanctioned no-fly zone over Libya, alongside a military operation to prevent further attacks on civilians and civilian-populated areas, undertaken by a multinational coalition under British, France and US command; on 27 March, NATO mem. states agreed to assume full command of the operation to protect civilians in Libya; the Operation was extended for 90 days from 27 June, and for a further 90 days in late Sept.

in late Oct., following the capture by opposition forces of the last remaining govt-controlled city, Sirte, and the arrest (and subsequent death) of the Libyan leader, Col Muammar al-Qaddafi, the NAC authorized the conclusion of the Operation with effect from the end of that month

leaders attending the Sept. 2014 Newport, UK summit meeting of NATO heads of state and govt expressed willingness to develop a long-term partnership with Libya, possibly leading to that country’s membership in the Alliance’s so-called Mediterranean Dialogue
Iraq was granted NATO partner status in April 2011; in early 2012 a NATO Transition Cell was established in Iraq to support the devt of the partnership

in June 2012 the NAC met, at the request of Turkey (officially known as Türkiye since 1 June 2022), in accordance with Article 4 of the North Atlantic Treaty—invoked when the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the parties is threatened—following the shooting down by Syrian forces of a Turkish military jet; in Dec. NATO ministers of foreign affairs agreed to strengthen Turkey's air defence capabilities along its border with Syria; meeting in late Aug. 2013 the NAC strongly condemned the apparent use on 21 Aug. of chemical weapons against civilians in Ghouta, Damascus, Syria; the NAC determined to continue closely to review the situation in Syria and to continue to support Turkey in protecting the Alliance’s south-eastern border

in July 2015 NATO’s Sec.-Gen. strongly condemned a bomb attack on the town of Suruç, in southeastern Turkey, near its border with Syria, which had resulted in around 30 fatalities and numerous injuries; at the end of the month, at the request of the Turkish Govt, under Article 4 of the North Atlantic Treaty, the NAC gathered again to consider the ongoing threat to peace and security in Turkey; the Council expressed strong solidarity with that country, and determined to observe closely the situation in the southeastern border area; in late Nov. an extraordinary meeting of the NAC emphasized solidarity with Turkey following the shooting down of a Russian plane that had entered its airspace

in May 2017 the NATO Sec.-Gen. stated that the Alliance would participate formally in a non-combat capacity in the global coalition against Islamic State, and noted that a recently established Joint Intelligence and Security Division would place a particular focus on foreign fighters travelling to Iraq and Syria

in Feb. 2017 NATO defence ministers agreed to establish a regional Hub for the South, to address threats arising from North Africa and the Middle East; this—based at Joint Allied Force Command Naples (Italy)—was declared fully operational in July 2018

in July 2018, at the request of the Iraqi Govt—which had declared victory over Islamic State in December 2017—NATO heads of state and govt authorized a new NATO Mission Iraq (NMI), with a focus on training; the NMI was established in Oct. 2018; in early Jan. 2020 NATO temporarily suspended the NMI’s activities, for safety reasons, following the assassination on 2 Jan., on Iraqi soil, by a US air strike, of Gen. Qassem Soleimani, commander of the elite Quds Force unit of the Iranian Revolutionary Guards Corps; on 6 Jan. the Iraqi legislature passed a non-binding resolution demanding that foreign military forces withdraw from Iraq and cease using its land, waters and airspace; NATO’s Sec.-Gen. reiterated that the killing was an act made unilaterally by the US Administration, and noted that there was consensus among the NATO Allies in condemning support by Iran for various terrorist groups, unanimous agreement that Iran should never acquire nuclear weaponry, and concern over a recent escalation of provocations and hostile acts perpetrated by Iran

in Feb. 2021 NATO ministers responsible for defence determined to strengthen and expand the NMI from 500 to 4,000 personnel, on the basis of a request by the Iraqi Govt, with a focus on countering the continuing threat from Islamic State

in June 2022 a trilateral memorandum was concluded between Finland, Sweden and Türkiye which addressed the latter’s concerns that, upon the planned admission of those countries into the org., any arms exports should not assist the separatist Kurdistan Workers’ Party—Partiya Karkeren Kurdistan

in mid-March 2023, following a meeting with his Finnish counterpart, Türkiye’s Pres. Recep Tayyip Erdoğan announced that, as Finland had taken `authentic and concrete’ measures to address Türkiye’s security concerns (as agreed in the June 2022 Trilateral Memorandum), ratification of that country’s NATO application would proceed through the Turkish legislature; this was effected at the end of March 2023; on 4 April Finland formally deposited its instrument of accession to NATO; in July Pres. Erdoğan gave his approval for Sweden’s accession

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons

address.verbatim-address: Johan de Wittlaan 32, 2517 JR The Hague, Netherlands

org-entry.found-date: April 1997, on the entry into force of the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC)
org-entry.content-note: CWC states parties are obligated to declare any chemical weapons-related activities, to secure and destroy any stockpiles of chemical weapons within the stipulated deadlines; this was declared to have been achieved by July 2023
OPCW verifies the irreversible destruction of declared chemical weapons stockpiles, as well as the elimination of all declared chemical weapons production facilities

mem. states undertake to provide protection and assistance if chemical weapons have been used against, or threaten, a state party, and, together with OPCW inspectors, monitor the non-diversion of chemicals for activities prohibited under the CWC and verify the consistency of industrial chemical declarations
the OPCW is a lead partner in the UN Counter-Terrorism Implementation Task Force’s working group concerned with preventing and responding to weapons of mass destruction

in March 2013 the UN Sec.-Gen. invited the OPCW to assist a UN mission which was appointed at that time to investigate allegations relating to the use of chemical weapons by combatants in the ongoing conflict in Syria (which was not a signatory of the CWC)
in mid-Sept. the mission’s report confirmed that chemical weapons had been used in Syria

at that time the Syrian Govt deposited its instrument of accession to the CWC in accordance with a Russo-US agreement on a framework for the safeguarding and destruction of Syria's chemical weapons stockpiles

in Oct. the UN Security Council authorized the deployment of a jt OPCW-UN mission to supervise the destruction by the Syrian authorities of all chemical weapons stockpiles and production facilities; this was reportedly achieved by Aug. 2014 and the mission was terminated in the following month
from April 2014 an OPCW Fact-Finding Mission (FFM) was tasked with investigating the reported use of toxic chemicals for hostile purposes in Syria

from Aug. 2015-Nov. 2017 it was supported by a Joint Investigative Mechanism, comprising experts appointed by the UN and OPCW, and from 2019 by an OPCW Investigation and Inspection Team, which aimed to ascertain the perpetrators of any attacks

by Feb. 2024 the FFM had issued 21 reports covering 74 instances of alleged chemical weapons use (of which it concluded that chemical weapons were used or likely used in 20 instances, including in March 2017 at Ltamenah, April 2017 at Khan Sheikhoun, and Feb. 2018 at Saraqib)

in April 2018 the OPCW issued the findings of a technical assistance team that, at the request of the UK Govt, had investigated the nature of a nerve agent that had been deployed offensively in Salisbury, UK, in March
an OPCW Centre for Chemistry and Technology (the ChemTech Centre), incorporating the org.’s existing laboratory, was inaugurated in May 2023

Nicolas Maduro
a new org. to promote regional integration, Prosur , was established by the heads of state of 7 UNASUR mems (and by a rep. of Guyana) in March 2019
by that time Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay and Peru had all announced their departure from UNASUR
the withdrawal of Bolivia was announced in Nov., while Uruguay announced its withdrawal from the org. in March 2020

in early 2023 the recently elected Pres. of Brazil, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, indicated that Brazil intended to rejoin and revitalize UNASUR; this was formalized in May
